para.text: General.
Any person licensed under Natural Resources Article, §§4-210, 4-210.1, 4-701, 4-701.1, or 4-701.2, Annotated Code of Maryland:

Unless they have indicated on a form provided by the Department that they will not be participating in a fishery for a particular period of time, shall accurately record their harvest information in accordance with this regulation;
Shall declare their method of reporting on a form provided by the Department:
At the time of obtaining a license; and
When renewing the license; and
May change their reporting declaration not more than two times per license year on a form provided by the Department.
Licensees are required to report:
Oyster harvest, only if they have paid the oyster surcharge in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Clam harvest, only if they have declared to harvest clams in accordance with COMAR 08.02.08.05; and
Guided fishing activities, only if they provide services as a fishing guide.
For purposes of this regulation, the time period for reporting fishing guide activities is Sunday through Saturday.
Electronic reports submitted in accordance with this regulation satisfy the paper reporting requirements described in this subtitle.

A licensee shall submit the completed paper reports as required in §B of this regulation unless the licensee has indicated on a form provided by the Department that the licensee will report electronically in accordance with §§C or D of this regulation.
An individual who is authorized to use a licensee’s commercial license and vessel in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland:
Shall report in the same manner as the licensee; and
May not participate in the regulatory exceptions described in §§E-K of this regulation.
Paper Reports.

During the appropriate open seasons, the following reports shall be submitted to the Department following the instructions detailed on the report not later than the 10th day of the month immediately following the month that the report pertains to:

para.text: In accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, the Department may suspend a person's tidal fish license, authorization, or entitlement to engage in a particular activity or activities under a tidal fish license if the reports described in §B of this regulation are not received by the Department within 50 days of the due date described in §B(1) of this regulation.
The maximum penalty for failing to submit reports within 50 days of the due date described in §B(1) of this regulation shall be as follows:

The “Number of Late Reports” described in §B(3) of this regulation means the number of late reports the Department has recorded for each individual report required by §B(1) of this regulation in any 12-month period.
The Department may only suspend a licensee under this regulation from participating in the fishery or fisheries to which the reporting violations pertain.
The Department may impose less than the maximum suspension.

Before the Department imposes a suspension or revocation under this regulation, an individual is entitled to a contested case hearing upon request in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Electronic Harvest Reporting without Hailing.

A licensee who declares electronic harvest reporting without hailing as their method of reporting shall accurately record their harvest information in a system approved by the Department or in a comparable federal system approved by the Department.
The Department shall post on its website the systems approved under this section.
A licensee shall report their harvest information by the earlier deadline of:
The 10th day of the month immediately following the month that the report pertains to; or
The timeframe required by the federal agency which requires the submission of the report.
Electronic Harvest Reporting with Hailing—General.
A licensee who declares electronic harvest reporting with hailing as their method of reporting:
Shall accurately record their harvest information in an electronic format prescribed by the Department;
May choose to participate in the exceptions described in §§E–K of this regulation; and
Shall return all paper striped bass or yellow perch permit cards that have been issued by the Department.
A licensee is not required to report on the days that they do not engage in activities authorized under their license.
Hailing Requirements.
Prior to the vessel being underway, a licensee shall send a start hail following the method prescribed by the electronic system.
A licensee shall send an end hail:
That includes the required information;
Following the method prescribed by the electronic system;
Within 30 minutes of completion of harvest activity; and
Prior to landing the harvest.
A licensee shall revise their start hail prior to sending their end hail if the original information reported is no longer accurate.
A licensee shall revise their end hail catch information if the original information reported is no longer accurate.
Vessel Marking Requirements.
The markings described in this section shall be displayed on the vessel at all times if the licensee has declared electronic harvest reporting with hailing as their method for reporting harvest.
The markings described in this section shall be removed from the vessel upon declaring to report harvest using paper or electronic reporting without hailing.

The letters for the abbreviation of the report being submitted electronically shall be identified and displayed on the vessel and shall be painted or firmly attached to the port side near the stern of the vessel as follows:
The letters shall be positioned in such a manner as to be clearly visible to persons in passing boats;
The letters shall be plain vertical block characters of not less than 3 inches in height and shall contrast with the color of the background;
The letters "EHRC" shall be displayed when harvesting blue crabs;
The letters "EHRS" shall be displayed when harvesting oysters, soft-shell clams, or hard-shell clams;
The letters "EHRG" shall be displayed when operating a guided fishing trip; and
The letters "EHRF" shall be displayed when harvesting all other fish species.
If a licensee is participating in more than one fishery, the licensee may display a combination of letters described in §D(3)(c) of this regulation as directed by the Department.
The exceptions described in §§E—K of this regulation are available only to a licensee who has declared electronic harvest reporting with hailing as their method of reporting.

If a licensee on a vessel participates in an exception described in §§E—K of this regulation, all licensees on board that vessel shall report their harvest information in the electronic harvest reporting with hailing system.
Electronic Harvest Reporting with Hailing—Blue Crabs.
For purposes of this section, the crabbing week is Wednesday through Tuesday.
Except as permitted in COMAR 08.02.03.14B, a licensee or vessel may not set or retrieve gear or catch blue crabs for commercial purposes more than 6 days during any crabbing week.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.03.14, a licensee is not required to take their declared day off.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.03.11, the licensee:
May set crab pots and remove blue crabs from crab pots in the Chesapeake Bay up to 2 hours before sunrise; and
May, on July 3 and July 4, set crab pots and remove crabs from crab pots in the Chesapeake Bay up to 3 hours before sunrise.
If a licensee begins removing blue crabs prior to the start times listed in COMAR 08.02.03.11, the licensee:
Shall cease removing crabs from crab pots not more than 6 hours after sunrise; and
May set crab pots already onboard a vessel up to 1 hour after the end of the time period established in §E(5)(a) of this regulation.

If a licensee on a vessel participates in the harvest hours described in §E(4) of this regulation, all licensees on board that vessel shall adhere to the time periods described in §E(5) of this regulation.
Electronic Harvest Reporting with Hailing— Oysters.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.04.03, a licensee may:
Begin harvesting up to 1 half hour before sunrise; and
Designate a representative in the electronic harvest reporting system to deliver their oysters to a dealer if the designated representative:
Is commercially licensed to harvest oysters;
Has purchased the oyster surcharge; and
Has declared to report harvest using the electronic harvest reporting system with hailing.
A licensee who begins harvest activity early shall cease harvest one half hour earlier than the stop times listed in COMAR 08.02.04.03.

If a licensee on a vessel participates in the harvest hours described in §F(1)(a) of this regulation, all licensees on board that vessel shall adhere to the time periods described in §F(2) of this regulation.
Electronic Harvest Reporting with Hailing—Soft-Shell Clams.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.02.03, a licensee may:
Begin harvesting up to one half hour before sunrise; and
Designate a representative in the electronic harvest reporting system to deliver their soft-shell clams to a dealer if the designated representative:
Is commercially licensed to harvest soft-shell clams;
Has declared their intent to harvest soft-shell clams in accordance with COMAR 08.02.08.05; and
Has declared to report harvest using the electronic harvest reporting system with hailing.
A licensee who begins harvest activity early shall cease harvest 1 half hour earlier than the stop times listed in COMAR 08.02.02.03.

If a licensee on a vessel participates in the harvest hours described in §G(1)(a) of this regulation, all licensees on board that vessel shall adhere to the time periods described in §G(2) of this regulation.
Electronic Harvest Reporting with Hailing—Hard-Shell Clams.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.07.03, a licensee may:
Begin harvesting up to 1 half hour before sunrise; and
Designate a representative in the electronic harvest reporting system to deliver their hard-shell clams to a dealer if the designated representative:
Is commercially licensed to harvest hard-shell clams;
Has declared their intent to harvest hard-shell clams in accordance with COMAR 08.02.08.05; and
Has declared to report harvest using the electronic harvest reporting system with hailing;
A licensee who begins harvest activity early shall cease harvest 1 half hour earlier than the stop times listed in COMAR 08.02.07.03.

If a licensee on a vessel participates in the harvest hours described in §H(1)(a) of this regulation, all licensees on board that vessel shall adhere to the time periods described in §H(2) of this regulation.

Electronic Harvest Reporting with Hailing—Fishing Guides. Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.15.12, the captain and one mate may each possess up to one striped bass per person per day for personal consumption during the open recreational and charter boat summer and fall fishery.
Electronic Harvest Reporting with Hailing—Striped Bass.

The Department may not issue a physical striped bass permit to a licensee who has registered for a striped bass permit and declares their reporting method to be electronic harvest reporting with hailing.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.15, a licensee:
Is not required to have their striped bass permit in possession;
Is not required to record their harvest on their striped bass permit;
Shall have their striped bass counted and weighed by a Department representative at a check station not later than the day immediately following harvest; and
May designate an individual to take their striped bass to be counted and weighed at a check station only if the:
Licensee has designated the individual in the electronic harvest reporting system; and
Catch is counted and weighed the same day as harvested.
Electronic Harvest Reporting with Hailing—Yellow Perch.
The Department may not issue a physical yellow perch harvest permit to a licensee who has declared their:
Intent to fish for yellow perch; and
Reporting method to be electronic harvest reporting with hailing.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.21.03, a licensee:
Prior to landing, shall:
Except for the actual weight, complete all fields on the Department-issued tag;
Affix the Department-issued tag to each container of yellow perch; and
Include the sum of all containers for the number of fish and the estimated weight with the end hail;
Is not required to have their yellow perch permit in possession; and
Is not required to record their harvest on their yellow perch permit;
After the fish from each container are weighed and packed for transport the:
Licensee shall revise the end hail and provide the actual weight for each container; and
Tag shall be:
Removed from the container; and
Retained by the licensee.
In the manner specified by the Department, the licensee shall return the:
Used tags at the end of each month during the season; and
Unused tags at the end of the season.

para.text: Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries.
Quota. The annual target harvest for the commercial fishery is 42.5 percent of the overall Maryland quota.
Size Limits.
The minimum legal size for the commercial fishery is 18 inches total length.
The maximum legal size for the commercial fishery is 36 inches total length.
Seasons. The commercial seasons for taking striped bass for permittees registered in the Chesapeake Bay individual transferrable quota fishery are as follows:
The haul seine season is June 1 through the last day of February;
The hook and line season is June 1 through December 31;
The pound net season is June 1 through December 31; and
The drift gill net season is December 1 through the last day of February.
The Secretary shall allocate the annual target harvest for the following fisheries:
Chesapeake Bay Individual Transferrable Quota; and
Atlantic Ocean, its coastal bays and their tidal tributaries.
Initial Calculation of Shares in the Fisheries of the Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries.

A tidal fish licensee with a striped bass permit registered in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries as of May 10, 2013 shall receive a share of the striped bass fishery in accordance with this section.
Pound Net and Haul Seine.
The amount of shares to be divided among the pound net and haul seine fisheries is 33 percent of the Chesapeake Bay commercial quota.
Tidal fish licensees with a striped bass permit registered in the pound net fishery as of May 10, 2013 shall each receive an equal share.

Tidal fish licensees with a striped bass permit registered in the haul seine fishery as of May 10, 2013 shall each receive a share equal to the amount of one third of the share assigned to a striped bass permit registered in the pound net fishery as of May 10, 2013.
Gill Net and Hook and Line.
The amount of shares to be divided among the gill net and hook and line fisheries is 67 percent of the overall commercial quota.

Each tidal fish licensee with a striped bass permit registered in either the gill net or hook and line fisheries as of May 10, 2013 shall receive an equal share of 25 percent of the gill net and hook and line quota.

In addition to the initial baseline share described in §A(6)(c)(ii) of this regulation, each tidal fish licensee with a striped bass permit registered in either the gill net or hook and line fisheries as of May 10, 2013 may receive additional shares of the remaining 75 percent of the gill net and hook and line quota based on the average poundage of the striped bass harvested by the permittee during the period January 1, 2001 through February 29, 2012.
The Secretary may:
Reassign a commercial tidal fish licensee's allocation if the licensee has not registered for the allocation;
Modify the allocation of all commercial tidal fish licensees during the season;
Consider an appeal of the initial calculation of shares in the fisheries of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries under §A(6) of this regulation; and
Modify the shares of all commercial tidal fish licensees in an equal manner prior to the beginning of the quota year.

A flag specified by the Department shall be displayed on the vessel at least 3 feet above the surface on which it is mounted and clearly visible to approaching vessels if the individuals on board are engaged in commercial striped bass fishing to denote whether the individuals on board are participating in the Chesapeake Bay individual transferrable quota fishery.
Atlantic Ocean, its Coastal Bays and Their Tributaries.
Quota. The annual target harvest for the commercial fishery is the quota set by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission.
Minimum Size. The minimum legal size for the commercial fishery is 24 inches.
Season. The commercial season for the taking of striped bass for all gears is October 1 through May 31.
A striped bass caught in the waters of the State shall be landed in the State.

The Department may waive the provisions set forth in §B(4) of this regulation if an individual files with the Department an affidavit signed by the individual which specifies the out-of-State landing location and Maryland check station where fish will be counted and weighed.

The Secretary may modify the number of licensees with individual permits that may catch striped bass on a boat on any day by publishing notice in a daily newspaper of general circulation at least 48 hours in advance of the time of modification, stating the effective hour and date.
Initial Calculation of Shares in the Atlantic Ocean, Its Coastal Bays, and Their Tidal Tributaries.

A tidal fish licensee with a striped bass permit registered in the Atlantic Ocean, its coastal bays, and their tidal tributaries shall receive a share of the striped bass fishery in accordance with this section.
A tidal fish licensee shall receive an equal share for each of their permits registered in the Atlantic Ocean fishery.
A tidal fish licensee may receive a maximum share equal to four permits registered in the Atlantic Ocean fishery.
Drift Gill Net Fishery Limitations.
The provisions of this section apply to a commercial tidal fish licensee participating in a striped bass gill net season.
In the tidal waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries:
Only attended drift gill nets, as defined in COMAR 08.02.25.01B, with a stretched mesh size of not less than 5 inches or greater than 7 inches are permitted for the taking of striped bass;
The total length of drift gill net aboard a boat may not exceed 3,500 yards and may not be contained in more than ten containers;
A gill net may not be used to harvest fish or possessed aboard a vessel, unless the gill net has:
Each marker, cork, or float marked with the licensee's commercial tidal fish number; or
A float line with a marker permanently affixed every 50 feet bearing the licensee's commercial tidal fish number; and
A drift gill net may be used on a Saturday or Sunday.
A person may possess and use other legal fishing equipment to catch other fish species while fishing for striped bass with gear as provided in §C(2)(a) of this regulation.
A drift gill net may not be set before 3 a.m. and shall be retrieved and in the boat by 6 p.m.
Flag Marker — Chesapeake Bay or Atlantic Ocean.

A drift gill net set in the Chesapeake Bay or Atlantic Ocean shall be marked, by the licensee, at one end by a square flag measuring at least 144 square inches, supported by a staff sufficient to maintain the flag bottom at least 3 feet above the surface of the water.
The end of a gill net opposite the flag marker shall be marked by either a triangular flag of at least 144 square inches or a floating marker with a volume of at least 460 cubic inches.
Each flag or floating marker shall be marked with the licensee's commercial tidal fish license number.

Flag Marker Tributaries. A drift gill net set in tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay or Atlantic coastal bays and their tributaries shall be marked by the licensee at each end with a floating marker with a volume of at least 460 cubic inches, each bearing the licensee's commercial tidal fish license number, or a flag according to §A(8) of this regulation.

Gill Net and Gill Net Reels — Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries. Except during the commercial striped bass gill net season as specified in §A of this regulation or disseminated by public notice in accordance with Regulation .12H of this chapter, an individual may not catch and possess striped bass if a gill net or gill net reel is aboard the vessel.
Commercial Hook and Line Fishery Limitations. While using commercial hook and line, a person may not catch or attempt to catch striped bass:
Between 1 hour after sunset and 1 hour before sunrise; or
At any time on a Saturday or Sunday.
Pound Net Fishery Limitations.
A commercial tidal fish licensee may not harvest striped bass from a pound net between 6 p.m. and 12 a.m.
A commercial tidal fish licensee may not harvest striped bass from a pound net on Sunday.
A commercial tidal fish licensee shall comply with all additional requirements in the pound net fishery as described in COMAR 08.02.25.07.
General.
A commercial tidal fish licensee may not catch striped bass between 6 p.m. Friday and 5 a.m. Monday, except as provided in §§C, D, and E of this regulation.
Atlantic Tolerance.

A commercial tidal fish licensee registered in the Atlantic fishery is not in violation of this chapter if their landings do not exceed their allocation by more than the tolerance described in §F(2)(b) of this regulation.

The tolerance for the Atlantic fishery is the greater of either 50 pounds or 4 percent of the remaining allocation available to the permit holder on the final trip when the allocation is fully harvested.
A commercial tidal fish licensee registered in the Chesapeake Bay individual transferable quota fishery who exceeds their allocation by 50 pounds or less is not in violation of this chapter.

If a commercial tidal fish licensee registered in the Chesapeake Bay individual transferable quota or Atlantic fishery exceeds the licensees allocation, that overage may be deducted from the allocation the licensee receives in the next practicable quota year.

If a commercial tidal fish licensee registered in the Chesapeake Bay individual transferable quota fishery accumulates 10 or more points for offenses specific to the striped bass fishery as described in COMAR 08.02.13.02 and .03, that licensee shall be suspended for one quota year.
A commercial tidal fish licensee may catch striped bass using only the striped bass permit assigned to the licensee.

Administrative Days. The Department shall pay at the daily rate based on the patient’s ASAM level of care when:
The participant’s required level of care has changed, and the following conditions are met:
The provider has implemented a predischarge planning program and initiated placement activities for the participant at the earliest appropriate time;
The provider has actively pursued placement of the participant at the required level of care in an appropriate facility during the entire period of administrative days;

The provider has submitted documentation to the Department or its designee that it has complied with the requirements of §E(1)(a)—(b) of this regulation for the entire period of the administrative stay claimed for reimbursement; and
The participant is transferred promptly to the first available appropriate facility licensed and certified for the required level of care; and
The participant is at an inappropriate level of care but cannot be moved, and the following conditions are met:
The attending physician has declared that, because of physical or emotional problems, the participant is unable to be moved; and
The reason the participant cannot be moved is adequately documented by the attending physician in the participant’s record.

para.text: Requests for Payment.
All requests for payment of services rendered shall be submitted in accordance with COMAR 10.09.36.
Billing time limitations for claims submitted pursuant to this chapter are set forth in COMAR 10.09.36.

Payment to a provider shall be limited to the number of days each participant attends the medical day care center, as authorized by a participant’s home and community based services waiver service plan.

Payment shall be made only to a qualified medical day care provider. Payment may not be made to a participant, or to individual nurses, physicians, social workers, activity coordinators, or aides for services rendered in connection with the provision of medical day care.
Per Diem Rate.
Payment to a medical day care services provider shall be as follows:
For dates of service from January 1, 2021 through October 31, 2021, $88.95 per diem;
For dates of service from November 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022, $93.58 per diem;
For dates of service [on or after] from July 1, 2022 through December 31, 2023, $104.81 per diem;
For dates of service from January 1, 2024 through June 30, 2024, $113.19 per diem; and
For dates of service on or after July 1, 2024, $116.59 per diem.
Subject to the limitations of the State budget, the per diem rate shall increase on July 1 of each year by 4 percent.
Payment to a provider of medical day care services may not exceed the lesser of the:
Per diem rate established under §D of this regulation; or
Provider's customary charge to the general public for services covered by the Program, unless the service is free to individuals not covered by Medicaid.
If the service is free to individuals not covered by Medicaid:
The provider:
May charge the Program; and
Shall be reimbursed in accordance with §D of this regulation; and
The provider’s reimbursement is not limited to the provider’s customary charge.

para.text: Request for Payment.
Requests for payment for the services covered under this chapter shall be submitted by a provider according to procedures set forth in COMAR 10.09.36.04.
Billing time limitations for services covered under this chapter are the same as those set forth in COMAR 10.09.36.06.
Payment Rates.
The Department shall publish a fee schedule for services covered under this chapter, which shall be publicly available and updated at least annually or upon any changes made by the Department.

The Department's rates set forth in its fee schedule will apply to services covered under this chapter that are provided under either the traditional services delivery model or the self-directed services delivery model.
The Program's rates for covered services under this chapter shall increase on July 1 of each year, subject to the limitations of the State budget.
Providers shall be reimbursed within 45 business days of approved invoice for services rendered based on the rates set forth in §C(1) and (2) of this regulation.
For a comprehensive assessment, providers shall be reimbursed $450 per assessment.
For all other services rendered to Maryland Medicaid participants residing in counties other than those listed in §B(7) of this regulation, providers shall be reimbursed:
For dates of service January 1, 2023 through June 30, 2023, $24.56 per unit;
For dates of service July 1, 2023 through December 31, 2023, $25.54 per unit;
For dates of service January 1, 2024 through June 30, 2024, $27.50 per unit; and
For dates of service July 1, 2024 through June 30, 2025, $28.33 per unit.
Providers rendering services to Maryland Medicaid participants residing in Calvert, Charles, Frederick, Montgomery, and Prince George’s counties shall be reimbursed:
For dates of service January 1, 2023 through June 30, 2023, $25.86 per unit;
For dates of service July 1, 2023 through December 31, 2023, $26.89 per unit;
For dates of service January 1, 2024 through June 30, 2024, $28.96 per unit; and
For dates of service July 1, 2024 through June 30, 2025, $29.83 per unit.
Changes in Rates.
The rates are subject to the limitations of the State budget.
Unless otherwise authorized, the rates may be changed on July 1 of each year beginning July 1, 2015, based on legislative action, and subject to limitations of the State budget.
Payment Limitations.
Payment shall be made only to one provider for covered services rendered to a participant on a particular date of service.
Payment for the services covered under this chapter:
Shall be considered as payment in full; and
May not supplement or be supplemented by payment from other sources, such as the participant, family, a public program, or private agency.
For a comprehensive assessment, only one assessment may be reimbursed per participant, unless otherwise authorized by DDA.
Ongoing coordination of community services shall be billed on a scheduled determined by the Department.
Units of Services and Limitations.
All coordination of community services other than the initial comprehensive assessment shall be billed to DDA in units of service.
DDA shall provide payment for only those coordination of community services that were authorized by DDA before the provision of the service.
Each fiscal year, the coordinator of community services shall complete the core services for each participant.

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: These regulations govern the use of quiet rooms and restraint in all facilities as defined in Health-General Article, §§10-101(g) and 10-701, Annotated Code of Maryland. These regulations are supplemental to any other applicable law and regulation. In the event of conflict between these regulations and any other regulations or laws, the more stringent apply.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
Category I Restraint.

“Category I restraint” means a device identified by the facility which limits a patient's mobility to the extent that the patient would not be able to independently reposition himself or herself or would otherwise be rendered helpless in an emergency.
“Category I restraint” includes, but is not limited to, four-point restraints.
“Category II restraint” means any device which is not considered by the facility as a category I restraint and includes, but is not limited to, mittens and vests.
“Chief executive officer (CEO)” means the individual responsible for the overall management of a facility.
“Child” means an individual younger than 12 years old.
“Clinical director” means the psychiatrist in charge of the clinical care of all psychiatric patients in the facility.
“Emergency situation” means a situation in which a patient's behavior poses a serious and imminent danger to the physical safety of self or others.

“Facility” means any public or private hospital, clinic, or other institution that provides or purports to provide treatment or other services for a mental disorder, except an acute general hospital that does not have a separately identified inpatient psychiatric service.
“Full view” means the unobstructed view by the assigned staff of a restrained patient.
“Patient” means an individual receiving services for a mental disorder in a facility and includes any student receiving care and treatment in that facility.
“Physician” means an individual who is authorized to practice medicine under Health Occupations Article, Title 14, Annotated Code of Maryland.

“Protective device” means any adaptive or assistive device or devices which restrict the movement of the whole or a portion of a patient's body for the purpose of preventing unintentional harm to self or others or which are used for promoting or maintaining normative body functions.
Prone Restraint.
“Prone restraint” means restricting the free movement of all or a portion of a patient’s body through the use of physical force or mechanical devices while the patient is in a prone position.
“Prone restraint” does not mean a technique for transitioning a patient to a restraint position that involves momentarily placing the individual face down.
“Quiet room” means an unlocked room that patients are not physically prevented from leaving, which is designated for patients' voluntary use to allow them time out of the company of other patients.
“Registered nurse” means an individual who is licensed to practice registered nursing under Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Restraint.
“Restraint” means:
Any manual method, physical or mechanical device, material, or equipment that immobilizes or reduces the ability of a patient to move their arms, legs, body, or head freely; or

A drug or medication when it is used as a restriction to manage the patient’s behavior or restrict the patient’s freedom of movement and is not a standard treatment or dosage for the patient’s condition.
“Restraint” does not include a helmet when used as a sole form of restraint or a protective device.
“Seclusion” means the involuntary confinement of a patient under the direction of a physician or registered nurse alone in a room which a patient is physically prevented from leaving.
“Trauma-informed care” means mental health treatment that includes:
An appreciation for the high prevalence of trauma experienced by individuals receiving mental health services;
An understanding of the neurological, biological, psychological, and social effects of trauma and violence, including sexual abuse and exploitation, on an individual; and
An understanding of the environment, practices, and treatments that may need to be modified to address trauma issues.
“Treatment team” means the patient's treatment team as defined in COMAR 10.21.03.02C.
Staff authorized under the provisions of Regulation .05B of this chapter may use a restraint:
Only during an emergency in which the behavior of the patient places the patient or others in serious threat of violence or injury;
If ordered by a physician in writing; or
If at the direction of a registered nurse, if a physician's order is obtained within 2 hours of the action.
Staff may not use a restraint:
As a mode or course of treatment;
As punishment, coercion, discipline, or retaliation;
For the convenience of staff;
To prevent damage or destruction to property; or
To prevent serious disruption of the therapeutic environment.
Staff shall use a restraint:
In a humane, safe, and effective manner;
Without intent to harm or create undue discomfort to the patient; and and
For the shortest possible length of time, regardless of the length of time in the physician's order.
Staff authorized under the provisions of Regulation .05B of this chapter may order the use of a restraint only if the physician, following a clinical evaluation of the patient, determines that:
The patient's behavior poses an emergency situation; and
Less restrictive or alternative approaches have been determined to be ineffective to ensure the safety of the patient, staff, or others.
The approaches referred to in §D(2) of this regulation may include, but are not limited to:
Clinical interventions;
Quiet room;
Medication or medications;
Deescalation techniques;
Trauma-informed care interventions;
Calling the hospital's response team for assistance; and
Consulting the patient's care plan for personalized strategies.

section.heading: Procedures in the Use of Restraint.

para.text: A facility shall:

Have a written policy specifying the method used to ensure that a patient whose primary language or method of communication is nonverbal is able to effectively communicate distress during a physical restraint or hold; and

Ensure that all staff at the facility who are authorized to participate in a physical restraint or hold of a patient are trained in the method specified in the written policy in accordance with §A(1) of this regulation.

A physician who is responsible either for the care of the patient or for assessment of the appropriateness of a restraint or, when the appropriate physician is not readily available to assess the patient, a registered nurse shall conduct a clinical evaluation of the patient to determine whether an emergency situation is present.

Before using restraint, the physician or registered nurse shall assess whether less restrictive or alternative approaches have been determined to be ineffective to ensure the safety of the patient, staff, or others.

When a physician, as identified in §B of this regulation, is immediately available, the physician shall be responsible for determining a patient's need for a restraint and make the decision whether to restrain.
Authorization in the Absence of a Physician.

When a physician, as identified in §B of this regulation, is not immediately available, a registered nurse shall determine a patient's need for restraint and may initiate and direct the use of restraint.

Within 2 hours of the implementation of the restraint, a physician shall give a written or verbal order for any restraint initiated by a registered nurse and, at that time, shall make the clinical determination to continue or to discontinue the restraint.
When possible, staff shall advise a patient, in a nonthreatening manner, that continuation of a specific behavior may result in the use of restraint.

When a physician or registered nurse determines that the use of a restraint is appropriate, staff involved shall make a reasonable effort to verbally persuade the patient to be cooperative with the restraint.
Staff shall apply a restraint only in accordance with the facility's policy and procedure manual.
For the patient's safety and the safety of others:
Staff shall place the patient in the restraint in as dignified a manner as the situation permits, using the least amount of physical force necessary;
As necessary, additional staff shall participate in the placement of a patient in restraint;
The patient shall be free from subject prone restraint; and
The patient shall be free from a restraint that:
Applies pressure to the patient’s back;
Obstructs the airway of the patient or impairs the patient’s ability to breathe;
Obstructs a staff member’s view of the patient’s face; or
Restricts the patent’s ability to communicate distress.
Unless a physician or registered nurse determines that it is unsafe to do so, staff shall permit the patient to wear all or a portion of the patient's own clothes or another form of attire.
Staff shall search the patient for potentially harmful objects.
If staff determine a need for objects to be removed pursuant to §F of this regulation, staff shall ask the patient, in a nonthreatening manner, to surrender the objects.
Unless contraindicated for safety reasons, staff shall permit the patient to wear eyeglasses, hearing aids, dentures, or prosthetic devices.
When placing a patient in a restraint, staff shall inspect each restraining device and ensure that each restraining device is safely and securely applied.
As necessary, staff shall ensure that each restraint is padded to provide appropriate protection for the patient.
Regardless of the physical setting in which the patient is placed, at a minimum, one staff member shall be assigned continuously while the patient is in a category I restraint.
While the patient is restrained, in order to provide appropriate clinical care, at a minimum, staff clinically trained to do so shall:
Keep the patient in full view at all times;
Protect the patient from harm by others;
Closely observe the patient at least every 15 minutes, and document each observation by the observer;
Unless contraindicated by circumstances as assessed and documented by a physician or registered nurse, at least hourly, make and document personal contact with the patient for the purpose of:
Determining if the patient has any special needs which need attention;
Checking circulation of the extremities restrained;
Adjusting the restraint; and
Realigning the body or massaging the extremities restrained, or both;
Unless contraindicated by circumstances as assessed and documented by a physician or registered nurse, offer or provide the following:
Full range of motion, every 2 hours;
Toilet facilities, at least every 2 hours;
Bathing and oral hygiene, at least once during a 24-hour period;
Meals, at the regularly scheduled hours and under the supervision of nursing personnel; and
Fluids, at least every 2 hours; and
As clinically indicated, record temperature, pulse, blood pressure, and respirations.

At least once every 2 hours, a physician or registered nurse shall assess the appropriateness of continuing the restraint and document the factors supporting the assessment in the patient's medical record.
When the patient's behavior no longer places the patient or others in serious threat of violence or injury, the patient shall be released from restraint.

section.heading: Limitations on Restraint and Continuous Restraint.

para.text: Staff may not initiate "standing" or "as needed" orders for restraint.

Each order for restraint, used for the management of an emergency in which the behavior of the patient places the patient or others in serious threat of violence or injury, may only be renewed in accordance with the following limits not to exceed 24 hours total:
Four hours for adults 18 years of age or older;
Two hours for children and adolescents 9 to 17 years of age; or
One hour for children under 9 years of age.

After 24 hours, before writing a new order for the use of restraint for the management of an emergency in which the behavior of the patient places the patient or others in serious threat of violence or injury, a physician must:
See, assess, and conduct a face-to-face evaluation of the patient to determine whether continuous restraint is appropriate;
Document in the patient's medical record the observed behavior that confirms that the patient, if released from restraint, would continue to present a danger to self or others;
Follow all requirements outlined in this chapter, including but not limited to §B of this regulation; and
Obtain the authorization of the clinical director or the clinical director's physician designee, neither of whom may be the treating physician.

Upon a request from a patient's treating physician, prior to authorizing continued restraint in accordance with §C(4) of this regulation, the clinical director or the clinical director's designee shall perform a face-to-face evaluation of the patient who is restrained.

Following the initial 24 hours of restraint authorized under §C of this regulation, additional periods of restraint, not to exceed 24 hours each, may be authorized only if the restraint is provided in accordance with §§B—D of this regulation.
Treatment Team Involvement.
Minimally, at regularly scheduled meetings, the patient's treatment team shall examine the use of restraint for that patient.
Within 5 working days from the initiation of continuous restraint, regardless of whether the patient remains in restraint, the treatment team shall:
When applicable, review the appropriateness of the continued use of restraint;
Establish and implement a plan to eliminate the need for further restraint; and
Identify a team member who shall explain to the patient the potential risks and benefits of continuous restraint.
Restraint Orders. A physician shall:
To initiate the use of restraint:
Enter an order in the patient's medical record; or
Authorize an order to be written by a registered nurse on the physician's order sheet in the patient's medical record:
Indicating that physician's verbal order for restraint; or
Directing the release of the patient and the rationale for that release;
Countersign all verbal orders within 24 hours of the order's being written; and
Include in the order for restraint:
The date and time that the order was written;
The specific type of restraint to be used;
The maximum duration of restraint from the time that the restraint was initiated;
The specific rationale for restraint;
Special precautions, if any, to safeguard the patient;
The physician's signature; and
In the case of a verbal order, the names of both the ordering physician and the registered nurse who received the verbal order.
As soon as possible after implementation, but not later than the close of the shift, staff shall:
Document the implementation of restraint in the patient's medical record; and
Include in the documentation the following information:
A description of the specific behavior leading to restraint;
Whether and which less restrictive techniques were used, and, if not, why not;
Whether a formal call for facility staff response was required, the names of staff assisting in the restraint, and the circumstances while restraining the patient;
The readily observable physical condition of the patient;
The date and time of the restraint and signature of the recorder;
Whether the patient was permitted to wear the patient's own clothes or other attire and, if not, the reason or reasons for this; and
A description of any physical injury to either the patient or others resulting from placement of the patient in restraint.
While a patient is restrained, staff shall document the clinical interventions employed, including those listed in Regulation .08 of this chapter.
Release from Restraint.
When a physician clinically determines that a patient is to be released from restraint, the physician shall:
Order the release and write, sign, and date a note indicating the rationale for the release; and
If verbally ordering the release, write, sign, and date the note not later than 24 hours after a verbal order to release.
When a registered nurse clinically determines that the release of the patient before the maximum period specified on a physician's order is appropriate, the registered nurse shall:
Direct termination of the restraint; and
Document, sign, and date the rationale for the termination of restraint in the patient's medical record.
The clinical director or the clinical director's designee shall review daily all uses of restraint and investigate unusual or possibly unwarranted patterns of use.
The physician involved in the restraint may not function in the capacity outlined in §A of this regulation.

A facility shall identify a committee to review periodically, but not less than quarterly, the use of restraint to assure that the standards maintained by the facility are, at a minimum, consistent with this chapter.
Staff who implement orders for restraint:
Shall have documented annual training in the proper use of physical restraint and hold including training for special populations which include, but are not limited to, children and the elderly;
Shall have documented annual training in trauma-informed care and demonstrate competency in providing trauma-informed care services; and
May not implement orders for restraint until trained by the facility to do so unless, in an emergency situation, the safety of the patient or others is threatened.

The facility's chief executive officer or the chief executive officer's designee is responsible for assuring that the restraint devices used in that facility are maintained in accordance with acceptable standards for hygiene and safety.
If seclusion is used in conjunction with restraint, staff shall also comply with COMAR 10.21.13.

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: These regulations govern the use of quiet rooms and seclusion in all facilities as defined in Health-General Article, §§10-101(g) and 10-701, Annotated Code of Maryland. These regulations are supplemental to any other applicable law and regulation. In the event of conflict between these regulations and any other regulations or laws, the more stringent apply.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Chief executive officer (CEO)” means the individual responsible for the overall management of a facility.
“Clinical director” means the psychiatrist in charge of the clinical care of all psychiatric patients in that facility.
“Emergency situation” means any situation in which a patient's behavior poses a serious and imminent danger to the physical safety of self or others.

“Facility” means any public or private hospital, clinic, or other institution that provides or purports to provide treatment or other services for a mental disorder, except an acute general hospital that does not have a separately identified inpatient psychiatric service.
“Patient” means an individual receiving services for a mental disorder in a facility and includes any student receiving care and treatment in that facility.
“Physician” means an individual who is authorized to practice medicine under Health Occupations Article, Title 14, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Prone Restraint.
“Prone restraint” means restricting the free movement of all or a portion of a patient’s body through the use of physical force or mechanical devices while the patient is in a prone position.
“Prone restraint” does not mean a technique for transitioning a patient to a restraint position that involves momentarily placing the individual face down.
“Quiet room” means an unlocked room that patients are not physically prevented from leaving, which is designated for patients' voluntary use to allow them time out of the company of other patients.
“Registered nurse” means an individual who is licensed to practice registered nursing under Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Seclusion” means the involuntary confinement of a patient under the direction of a physician or registered nurse alone in a room which a patient is physically prevented from leaving.
“Trauma-informed care” means mental health treatment that includes:
An appreciation for the high prevalence of trauma experienced by individuals receiving mental health services;
An understanding of the neurological, biological, psychological, and social effects of trauma and violence, including sexual abuse and exploitation, on an individual; and
(c ) An understanding of the environment, practices, and treatments that may need to be modified to address trauma issues.
“Treatment team” means the patient's mental health professional treatment team as defined in COMAR 10.21.03.02C.
Staff authorized under the provisions of Regulation .04C of this chapter may use seclusion:
Only during an emergency in which the behavior of the patient places the patient or others in serious threat of violence or injury; and
If ordered by a physician in writing; or
If at the direction of a registered nurse if a physician's order is obtained within 2 hours of the action.
Staff may not use seclusion:
As a mode or course of treatment;
As punishment, coercion, discipline, or retaliation;
For the convenience of staff;
To prevent damage or destruction to property; or
To prevent serious disruption of the therapeutic environment.
Staff shall conduct seclusion:
In a humane, safe, and effective manner;
Without intent to harm or create undue discomfort to the patient; and
For the shortest possible length of time, regardless of the length of time in the physician's order.
Staff authorized under the provisions of Regulation .04C of this chapter may order the use of seclusion only if that staff person, following a clinical evaluation of the patient, determines that:
The patient's behavior poses an emergency situation; and
Less restrictive or alternative approaches have been determined to be ineffective to ensure the safety of the patient, staff, or others.
The approaches referred to in §D(2) of this regulation may include, but are not limited to:
Clinical interventions;
Quiet room;
Medication or medications;
Deescalation techniques;
Trauma-informed care interventions;
Calling the hospital's response team for assistance; and
Consulting the patient's care plan for personalized strategies.

section.heading: Procedures in the Use of Seclusion.

para.text: A facility shall have a written policy specifying the method used to ensure that a patient whose primary language or method of communication is nonverbal is able to effectively communicate distress during a seclusion.

A facility shall ensure that all staff at the facility who are authorized to participate in a seclusion of patients are trained in the method specified in the written policy in accordance with §A(1) of this regulation.

A physician who is responsible either for the care of the patient or for assessment of the appropriateness of seclusion or, when the appropriate physician is not readily available to assess the patient, a registered nurse shall conduct a clinical evaluation of the patient to determine whether an emergency situation is present.

Before instituting seclusion, the physician or registered nurse shall assess whether less restrictive or alternative approaches have been determined to be ineffective to ensure the safety of the patient, staff, or others.

When a physician, as identified in §C of this regulation, is immediately available, the physician shall be responsible for determining a patient's need for seclusion and make the decision whether to seclude.
Authorization in the Absence of a Physician.

When a physician, as identified in §C of this regulation, is not immediately available, a registered nurse shall determine a patient's need for seclusion and may initiate and direct the use of seclusion.

Within 2 hours of the implementation of the seclusion, a physician shall give a written or verbal order for any seclusion initiated by a registered nurse and, at that time, shall make the clinical determination to continue or discontinue the seclusion.

section.heading: Placement of a Patient in a Seclusion Room.

para.text: When possible, staff shall advise a patient, in a nonthreatening manner, that continuation of a specific behavior may result in the use of seclusion.
When a physician or registered nurse determines that the use of seclusion is appropriate, staff involved shall make a reasonable effort to verbally persuade the patient to enter the seclusion room.
For patient's safety and the safety of others:
Staff shall place the patient in the seclusion room in as dignified a manner as the situation permits, using the least amount of physical force necessary;
As necessary, additional staff shall participate in the placement of a patient in seclusion;
The patient shall be free from prone restraint; and
The patient shall be free from restraint that:
Applies pressure to the individual’s back;
Obstructs the airway of the individual or impairs the individual’s ability to breathe;
Obstructs a staff member’s view of the individual’s face; or
Restricts the individual’s ability to communicate distress.
Unless a physician or registered nurse determines that it is unsafe to do so, staff shall permit the patient to wear all or a portion of the patient's own clothes or another form of attire.
Staff shall search the patient for potentially harmful objects.
If staff determines a need for objects to be removed pursuant to §E of this regulation, staff shall ask the patient, in a nonthreatening manner, to surrender the objects.
Unless contraindicated for safety reasons, staff shall permit the patient to wear eyeglasses, hearing aids, dentures, or prosthetic devices.
Staff shall inspect the seclusion room for potentially dangerous conditions and, as appropriate, shall fully secure the room.

If a patient is confined to a room in a manner that meets the definition of seclusion in accordance with Regulation .02B of this chapter, the patient is considered to be subject to seclusion, regardless of whether the room used is typically used as a seclusion room.
While the patient is secluded, in order to provide appropriate clinical care, at a minimum, clinically trained staff shall:
Observe the patient at least every 15 minutes, and document each observation by the observer;

Unless contraindicated by circumstances as assessed and documented by a physician or registered nurse, at least hourly, make and document personal contact with the patient for the purpose of determining if the patient has any special needs which need attention;
Unless contraindicated by circumstances as assessed and documented by a physician or registered nurse, offer or provide the following:
Toilet facilities, at least every 2 hours;
Bathing and oral hygiene, at least once during a 24-hour period;
Meals, at the regularly scheduled hours and under the supervision of nursing personnel; and
Fluids, at least every 2 hours; and
As clinically indicated, record temperature, pulse, blood pressure, and respirations.

At least once every 2 hours, a physician or registered nurse shall assess the appropriateness of continuing the seclusion and document the factors supporting the assessment in the patient's medical record.
When the patient's behavior no longer places the patient or others in serious threat of violence or injury, the patient shall be released from seclusion.

section.heading: Limitations on Seclusion and Continuous Seclusion.

para.text: Staff may not initiate “standing” or “as needed” orders for seclusion.

Each order for seclusion, used for the management of an emergency in which the behavior of the patient places the patient or others in serious threat of violence or injury, may only be renewed in accordance with the following limits not to exceed 24 hours total:
Four hours for adults 18 years of age or older;
Two hours for children and adolescents 9 to 17 years of age; or
One hour for children under 9 years of age.

After 24 hours, before writing a new order for the use of seclusion for the management of an emergency in which the behavior of the patient places the patient or others in serious threat of violence or injury, a physician must:
See, assess, and conduct a face-to-face evaluation of the patient to determine whether continuous seclusion is appropriate; and
Document in the patient's medical record the observed behavior that confirms that the patient, if released from seclusion, would continue to present a danger to self or others;
Follow all requirements outlined in this chapter, including but not limited to §B of this regulation; and
Obtain the authorization of the clinical director or the clinical director's physician designee, neither of whom may be the treating physician.

Upon a request from a patient's treating physician, prior to authorizing continued seclusion, in accordance with §C(4) of this regulation, the clinical director or the clinical director's designee shall perform a face-to-face evaluation of the patient who is secluded.

Following the initial 24 hours of seclusion authorized under §C of this regulation, additional periods of restraint, not to exceed 24 hours each, may be authorized only if the seclusion is provided in accordance with §§B—D of this regulation.
Treatment Team Involvement.
Minimally, at regularly scheduled meetings, the patient's treatment team shall review the use of seclusion for that patient.
Within 5 working days from the initiation of continuous seclusion, regardless of whether the patient remains in seclusion, the treatment team shall:
When applicable, review the appropriateness of the continued use of seclusion;
Establish and implement a plan to eliminate the need for further seclusion; and
Identify a team member who shall explain to the patient the potential risks and benefits of continuous seclusion.
Seclusion Orders. A physician shall:
To initiate the use of seclusion:
Enter an order in the patient's medical record; or
Authorize an order to be written by a registered nurse on the physician's order sheet in the patient's medical record:
Indicating that physician's verbal order for seclusion; or
Directing the release of the patient and the rationale for that release;
Countersign all verbal orders within 24 hours of the order's being written; and
Include in the order for seclusion:
The date and time that the order was written;
The maximum duration of seclusion from the time that the seclusion was initiated;
The specific rationale for seclusion;
Special precautions, if any, to safeguard the patient;
The physician's signature; and
In the case of a verbal order, the names of both the ordering physician and the registered nurse who received the verbal order.
As soon as possible after implementation, but not later than the close of the shift, staff shall:
Document the implementation of seclusion in the patient's medical record; and
Include in the documentation the following information:
A description of the specific behavior leading to seclusion;
Whether and which less restrictive techniques were used, and, if not, why not;
Whether a formal call for facility staff response was required, the names of staff assisting in the seclusion, and the circumstances while secluding the patient;
The readily observable physical condition of the patient;
The date and time of the seclusion and signature of the recorder;
Whether the patient was permitted to wear the patient's own clothes or other attire and, if not, the reason or reasons for this; and
A description of any physical injury to either the patient or others resulting from placement of the patient in seclusion.
While a patient is in seclusion, staff shall document in the patient's medical record the clinical interventions employed, including those listed in Regulation .06 of this chapter.
Release from Seclusion.
When a physician clinically determines that a patient is to be released from seclusion, the physician shall:
Direct termination of the seclusion with or without a physician's order; and
If verbally ordering the release, write, sign, and date the note not later than 24 hours after a verbal order to release.
When a registered nurse clinically determines that the release of the patient before the maximum period specified on a physician's order is appropriate, the registered nurse shall:
Order termination of the seclusion with or without a physician's order, unless the physician's order specifically requires physician concurrence with the termination; and
Document, sign, and date the rationale for the termination of seclusion in the patient's record.
The clinical director or the clinical director's designee shall review daily all uses of seclusion and investigate unusual or possibly unwarranted patterns of use.
The physician involved in the seclusion may not function in the capacity outlined in §A of this regulation.

A facility shall identify a committee to review periodically, but not less than quarterly, the use of seclusion to assure that the standards maintained by the facility are, at a minimum, consistent with this chapter.
Staff who implement orders for seclusion:
Shall have documented annual training in the proper use of seclusion including training for special populations which include, but are not limited to, children and the elderly;
Shall have documented annual training in trauma-informed care and demonstrate competency in providing trauma-informed care services;
May not implement orders for seclusion until trained by the facility to do so unless, in an emergency situation, the safety of the patient or others is threatened.
Standards for a Seclusion Room.
The CEO or the CEO's designee is responsible for assuring that the seclusion room or rooms in the facility are maintained in accordance with acceptable standards for hygiene and safety.
Staff shall ensure that each seclusion room:
Unless clinically contraindicated and the record reflects that assessment, has a mattress provided;
At the beginning of each shift, is inspected and maintained for proper temperature, ventilation, safety, lighting, sanitation, and freedom from dangerous conditions; and
Is fitted with a means of observation that affords staff a view of the entire room and permits clinical staff periodically to observe the patient.
If restraint is used in conjunction with seclusion, staff shall also comply with COMAR 10.21.12.
Excluding the prohibition described in §B of this regulation, staff may not vary from the standards identified in this chapter unless the variation is for an extreme crisis.
There may not be any variance with standards established in:
This regulation;
Regulation .03 of this chapter;
Regulation .04 of this chapter;
Regulation .05B—E, G, and I of this chapter;
Regulation .07A of this chapter;
Regulation .09 of this chapter;
Regulation .10A, D, E(1), and F of this chapter; and
Regulation .11 of this chapter.
Staff shall document, on the facility's variance report, a variance with standards permitted under this chapter.
The CEO shall rule on and document each variance permitted in §A of this regulation to determine whether the variance was:
An extreme crisis;
A deviation from the facility's procedure; or
A problem in the facility's policy which is correctable by administrative action.
The CEO shall assure that the facility's quality assurance process incorporates a monthly review of any variance permitted in §A of this regulation.

container.heading: Prescription Labeling for Blind, Visually Impaired, and Print Disabled Individuals

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Bag tag” means a receipt that may contain patient demographic information, drug information, and cost which is affixed to the bag containing the prescription drug vial or package.
“Blind” means:
A visual acuity not exceeding 20/200 in the better eye with corrective lenses; or
A visual field of which the widest diameter subtends an angle of not more than 20 degrees.
“Board” means the State Board of Pharmacy.
“Medical guide” means a medication guide approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as part of the prescription drug labeling for certain drugs when the FDA determines that:
Patient labeling could prevent serious adverse reactions;
The drug has serious risks that could affect the patient’s decision to use, or to continue to use, the product; or
Patient adherence to the directions for use is crucial to the drug’s effectiveness.
“Pharmacy” means an establishment holding a permit under Health Occupations Article, §12-401, Annotated Code of Maryland.

“Prescription label” means a label affixed to a prescription drug vial or package that contains the information required by State and federal laws, including any warnings or other information contained in auxiliary labels.
“Print disabled individual" means an individual who cannot effectively read print because of a visual, physical, perceptual, developmental, cognitive, or learning disability.
“Visually impaired individual” means an individual who has difficulty seeing even when wearing glasses.

A pharmacy shall adopt policies and procedures necessary to ensure that a blind, visually impaired, or print disabled individual has appropriate access to prescription labels, bag tags, and medical guides:
At no additional cost to the individual;
In a format through which the information is fully accessible to the individual;
Within a timeframe comparable to the timeframe within which the information is provided to an individual who is not blind, visually impaired, or print disabled; and
That contains the same information provided in a standard print prescription label, bag tag, or medical guide.

A prescription labeling, bag tag, or medical guide alternative provided under this chapter shall be in addition to the standard print prescription labeling, bag tag, or medical guide dispensed with a prescription drug.

section.heading: Prescription Labeling, Bag Tag, and Medical Guide Alternative—Requirements.

para.text: A pharmacist shall, upon request, provide at least one of the following alternative formats consistent with the needs of the blind, visually impaired, or print disabled individual:
Audio;
Braille;
Digital format; or
Large print.

A pharmacy shall implement policies and procedures to ensure that pharmacy staff provide verbal notice to any patient who may be blind, visually impaired, or print disabled that alternative prescription labeling, bag tags, and medical guides are available at no additional cost.
Notification Requirements.

A pharmacy shall notify the public that alternative prescription labeling, bag tags, and medical guides are available for blind, visually impaired, or print disabled individuals at no additional cost.
A pharmacy shall provide the information required by §C(1) of this regulation by:
Posting signage in a conspicuous location;
If applicable, including the information in the pharmacy’s telephone recording; and
If applicable, including the information on the pharmacy’s website.
The Board may take disciplinary action against a pharmacy or pharmacist for a violation of this chapter.

section.heading: Purpose and Scope.
section.text: This chapter applies to a comprehensive induction program for new teachers. The purpose of this regulation is to provide guidance for local school systems to establish a high quality induction program that addresses critical professional learning needs of new teachers, improves instructional quality, and helps inductees achieve success in their initial assignments, resulting in improved student learning and higher retention in the profession. Recognizing that "one-size-fits-all" induction programs do not meet the needs of new teachers, these regulations establish the components of an induction program, allowing local school systems to build on their current programs.

section.heading: Incorporation by Reference.
section.text: In this chapter, the following documents are incorporated by reference:

para.text: Standards for Professional Learning (Learning Forward, 2022);
InTASC Model Core Teaching Standards and Learning Progressions for Teachers 1.0 (Council of Chief State School Officers, 2013);
Social Justice Standards: The Teaching Tolerance Anti-Bias Framework (Southern Poverty Law Center, 2018);
International Society for Technology in Education Standards for Educators (International Society for Technology in Education, 2024); and
Model Code of Ethics for Educators (National Association of State Directors of Teacher Education and Certification, 2023).
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Mentee” means a public school teacher who receives the services of a mentor.

“Mentor” means a highly competent teacher selected by the local school system who will work to instill in a mentee the skills and knowledge necessary for student success in accordance with Regulation .05 of this chapter.
“New teacher” means a teacher who is:
Professionally licensed and has less than three years of teaching experience; or
A veteran who is new to the district. Holds a Conditional License or Resident Teacher License.
“Veteran teacher” means a professionally licensed teacher who is new to the local school system and has 3 or more years of teaching experience.
Each local school system shall establish and maintain a comprehensive induction program for all new teachers that is at least 3 years in duration.
Each local school system shall establish and maintain a comprehensive induction program for all veteran teachers that is at least 1 year in duration.

Each comprehensive induction program shall be designed with a coherent structure and consistent focus to ensure an integrated, seamless system of support for participating teachers and provide them with the knowledge and skills necessary to be successful in their classrooms and schools and prepare them to stay in the profession.
A comprehensive induction program may be developed and implemented in collaboration with an institution of higher education.
Each comprehensive induction program shall include:
An initial orientation;
Ongoing participation in an educator professional learning community​;
A plan for professional licensure, if applicable;

Specialized professional learning on the knowledge and skills new educators need that is aligned with the Maryland-recognized professional learning standards incorporated by reference in Regulation .02 of this chapter;

Professional learning on State and local school system initiatives and priorities, including the teacher evaluation system, career ladder for educators, and the College and Career Readiness Standards;
Professional learning and support for working with students with disabilities, multi-lingual learners, and differentiating instruction;

Professional learning for using technology in education aligned with the International Society for Technology in Education Standards for Educators incorporated by reference in Regulation .02 of this chapter;
Review and assessment of the principles of the Model Code of Ethics for Educators incorporated by reference in Regulation .02 of this chapter;
Job-embedded individualized and differentiated mentoring​;
Regularly scheduled opportunities for new teachers to observe and co-teach with skilled teachers, including follow-up discussions of the experiences​;
Assistance for new teachers with planning instruction;
Observations of instruction with feedback;
Ongoing professional learning on the multi-tiered system of supports (MTSS) framework to support all students; and
A schedule aligned to the Career Ladder for Educators​ established in Education Article, §6-1003, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Each local school system may identify a program coordinator who will plan and facilitate induction activities by:
Communicating with principals and other school leaders about induction activities;
Building and maintaining partnerships with local institutions of higher education to ensure a seamless transition from graduation to induction; and
Overseeing the evaluation of the comprehensive induction program.
The comprehensive induction program shall include ongoing professional learning for school leaders. Professional learning may address the following:
Retention strategies;
Creating the climate and systems for induction;
Working with mentors and new teachers; and
Aligning induction supports with local school system initiatives and strategies.

section.heading: Mentoring Component of the Comprehensive Induction Program.

para.text: A local school system shall establish an instructional mentoring program as part of its Comprehensive Induction Program.
The mentoring program shall provide individualized, instruction-focused, job-embedded support and mentoring that begins when a teacher is hired into the local school system.
The mentoring program shall include standards for effective mentoring that are:
Focused;
Systematic;
Ongoing;
Of high quality;
Geared to the needs of each teacher; and
Include observations with feedback.

The mentoring program shall include mentoring activities related to the Five Core Propositions of National Board Certification focusing on planning, instructional practices, and analyzing student learning.
The mentoring program shall support new teachers in developing culturally relevant teaching practices for all students.
To the extent practicable given staffing and fiscal concerns, each new teacher shall receive at least 400 minutes of mentoring per marking period.

A local school system and new teacher may mutually agree to a reduction in mentoring minutes per marking period if the new teacher achieves a rating of effective, or comparable, on a year-end evaluation.
The reduction of mentoring minutes per marking period shall not be less than:
300 minutes per marking period in year two of induction; and
200 minutes per marking period in year three of induction.
Each local school system shall have a rigorous selection process for mentors that includes:
Assurance that the mentor holds:
A Professional or Advanced Professional License; and
At least an effective, or comparable, rating on the most recent local school system evaluation;
A recommendation from a school or district leader who previously or currently supervises the individual and can attest to their readiness for the mentor role; and
Once the Career Ladder is well established, prioritization of those teachers with a designation of Lead, Distinguished, or Professor Distinguished Teacher.
Each local school system shall establish a process for matching mentors and mentees that:
Correlates licensure areas or grade bands, with the prioritization of the licensure area when possible; and
Considers diversity markers to the extent practicable.
Local school systems shall provide initial and ongoing training for mentors that may include:
Mentoring language and stances;
Key practices of a mentor, including differentiation of support;
Adult learning practices;
Elements of instructional mentoring, such as observations, planning, and analyzing student work;
Reflection on mentoring practice and communities of practice;
Anti-bias pedagogy aligned with the Social Justice Standards incorporated by reference in Regulation .02 of this chapter; and
Identification and coordination of appropriate resources to address the performance needs of mentees.
A mentor in the comprehensive induction program may not participate in the formal evaluation of a mentee.

section.heading: Evaluation of the Comprehensive Induction Program.

para.text: Local school systems shall evaluate the effectiveness of the comprehensive induction program.
Each local school system induction program shall develop a comprehensive evaluation plan that includes:
Mentee and mentor perception data of their overall induction experience;
Mentee experience data regarding their work with their mentor;
Mentor experience data regarding their work with their mentee;
Evidence of program components aligned to the:
Five Core Propositions of the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, which are:
Teachers are committed to students and their learning;
Teachers know the subjects they teach and how to teach those subjects to students;
Teachers are responsible for managing and monitoring student learning;
Teachers think systematically about their practice and learn from experience; and
Teachers are members of learning communities;
Model Code of Educator Ethics; and
InTASC Model Core Teaching Standards and Learning Progressions for Teachers 1.0;
Teacher growth data from the beginning to the end of the induction program as measured by the local school system teacher evaluation system;
Induction program participants' retention data; and
Evidence of the number of instructional-driven mentoring minutes every month.
Local school systems shall be in full compliance with this chapter by July 1, 2027.
Local school systems shall provide a report to the Department by July 1, 2027 that includes:
A description of the comprehensive induction program demonstrating compliance with this chapter; and
An evaluation plan that meets the requirements under Regulation .07 of this chapter.
Local school systems shall provide a report to the Department beginning July 1, 2029, and every 3 years thereafter, that includes:
Mentee and mentor data, including:
Mentee growth from the beginning to the end of the induction program;
Teacher retention;
The number of mentees participating in the comprehensive induction program;
The number of mentors assigned to teachers in the comprehensive induction program; and
The number of teachers who did not receive the minimum number of mentoring minutes per marking period under Regulation .05F of this chapter with an explanation of the reasons; and
The results of the evaluation of the comprehensive induction program developed under Regulation .06 of this chapter.
