para.text: This chapter applies to Electric System Plans for the advancement of the State policy goals and legislative intent set forth at Public Utilities Article, §§7-801—7-804, et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland, and all other relevant State goals and targets in effect during plan development. The objective of the final Electric System Plan is an electric system that advances State policy goals and is built in a manner that enables an electric company to provide safe, reliable, and cost-effective services and otherwise operates for the public good.
An Electric System Plan shall demonstrate a holistic approach to grid planning by:
Considering cost-effective solutions to electric system needs;
Incorporating new cost-effective technologies and analytical tools into planning processes to create a modern distribution system;
Utilizing real-time data to improve forecasting and planning for grid investments; and
Addressing issues related to other relevant Commission proceedings.
This chapter shall not become effective for electric cooperatives and municipal electric companies until January 1, 2028.
Electric company and gas company coordination on Electric System Plans may be performed, but shall not be required, unless required by law or as otherwise directed by the Commission.
Waiver of Regulations. Upon written request, a regulation in this chapter may be waived by the Commission for “good cause shown”.
Terms Defined.

“Annual Electric System Plan Update” means the update that electric companies publish annually at the end of the distribution system planning cycle in the years that they do not publish an Electric System Plan and that contains the information in Regulation .04B of this chapter.

“Baseline scenario” means an expected future state of a system or situation if no new interventions or policies are implemented beyond those already in place. It serves as a point of comparison to assess the impact of proposed actions or policies.
“Cost-effective” means having projected benefits that are greater than projected costs while considering other factors as determined by the Commission.

“Demand response” means changes in electric usage by demand-side resources from their normal consumption patterns in response to changes in the price of electricity over time or to incentive payments designed to induce lower electricity use at times of high wholesale market prices or ensure system reliability.
“Distributed energy resource (DER)” has the meaning stated in COMAR 20.50.09.02B.
“Distributed generation” means the same definition as Small Generator Facility in COMAR 20.50.09.02B.
“Electric company” has the meaning stated in Public Utilities Article, §1-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Energy storage device” has the meaning stated in Public Utilities Article, §7-216, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Electric System Plan” means the plan that electric companies publish pursuant to Regulation .04J of this chapter that concludes the distribution system planning cycle.
“Electric vehicle (EV)” has the meaning stated in COMAR 20.50.09.02B.
“Goal scenario” means a potential future state of a system or situation if policy goals are fully realized and it serves as a point of comparison to assess the progress towards policy goals.

“Grid needs” means the need for a specific mitigating action to alleviate an identified system constraint found during the electric system planning process. The specific characteristic of the system constraint and commensurate grid need will inform the solution that will mitigate the issue.

“Grid services” means the dispatch and control of one or more DERs to provide service to the electric company’s electric grid pursuant to an electric company tariff, service contract between the electric company and the owner of DERs or providing transmission-level grid services by participating in PJM Interconnection, LLC wholesale markets.
“Hosting capacity” has the meaning stated in COMAR 20.50.09.02B.

“Locational value assessment” means a process that provides price signals based on the benefits and costs of deploying distributed energy resources in a specific location and over time, considering grid conditions and the potential to defer or avoid traditional electric distribution infrastructure investments.

“Non-wires solution (NWS)” means a project or other solution that makes use of one or more DERs, technologies, and/or leads to the introduction of new or modification of existing energy management practices, standards, or protocols to address a system constraint or provide other grid services to the electric system.
“Planning metrics” means quantifiable measurements used to assess performance, track progress, and/or measure success of a process that an electric company electric system plan directly affects.
“Preliminary Electric System Plan” means the plan that electric companies file before the annual technical conference that contains the information in Regulation .04F of this chapter.
“Rightsizing” has the meaning stated in COMAR 20.50.09.02B.

“System constraints” means specific violations caused by physical characteristics of the electric distribution system exceeding electric company planning criteria, the result of which would threaten safe and reliable delivery of power.
“Stakeholder” means a person who is granted leave to intervene in an electric system plan proceeding pursuant to Public Utilities Article, §3-106, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Traditional wires solution” means a solution to address a system constraint that would be deferred or replaced by a non-wires solution.
“Virtual power plant (VPP)” has the meaning stated in Public Utilities Article, §7-216, Annotated Code of Maryland.
An electric system planning process shall align with the following components for each planning cycle and scenario and related requirements specified in this chapter:
Considerations feeding into types of projections;
Goals/ objectives;
DER forecast;
Load forecast;
Hosting capacity assessment;
Grid needs and locational value assessment;
Identify possible solutions to grid needs;
Screen and evaluate possible solutions;
Choose solutions and publish plan;
Program and project design; and
Assess results.
Considerations Feeding into Types of Projections.
Time Horizons for DER and Load Forecasting.
DER and load forecasting processes for electric companies other than electric cooperatives and municipal electric companies shall include at least three planning time horizons:
1 to 3 years;
4 to 6 years; and
7 to 10 years.
DER and load forecasting processes for electric cooperatives and municipal electric companies shall include at least two planning time horizons:
1 to 3 years; and
4 years up to 20 years.
Level of Granularity. The granularity of information in an electric system plan may vary as described in other sections of this regulation.
As a near-term objective:
Information shall be provided in an Electric System Plan at the substation level; and
Feeder-level information shall be provided as part of the planning process for feeders where there are identified system constraints;

As a longer-term objective, electric companies shall report on progress regarding incorporating more granular electric system and customer information and data into forecasting and planning processes in their electric system plan or annual electric system plan update.

Scenarios/Projections to be Analyzed. An electric system plan shall include a minimum of two scenarios to provide a range of outcomes to inform planning analysis and the determination of the scale and pace of grid needs:
A baseline scenario; and
A goal scenario.
The Commission may request an electric company to analyze scenarios in addition to a baseline scenario and goal scenario.
Data Sources, Scope, and Access. Electric companies shall provide for data collection and access that:
Allows stakeholders the opportunity to provide data inputs at pre-identified time periods defined by the electric company;
Provides collected data in a format that can be easily accessed by stakeholders; and
Provides stakeholders transparency into data sources, data and assumptions used to develop electric system plans and annual electric system plan updates.

Already-Approved Resource Retirements and Additions. Electric companies shall consider in their electric system plans whether distribution-level electric system planning can be used to mitigate potential gaps caused by generation retirements.
PJM Wholesale Markets. Electric companies shall consider DERs and VPPs that participate in the PJM wholesale markets in electric distribution planning as applicable.
Resource Costs and Capabilities. Electric companies contracting decisions to implement electric system plans and annual electric system plan updates shall be left to electric company discretion.

Goals/Objectives. An electric system plan shall promote applicable State policy goals pursuant to Public Utilities Article, §§7-801—7-804, et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland, and other applicable goals and targets as directed by the Commission.
DER Forecast. An electric system plan shall account for the following considerations for each electric system planning cycle and scenario.

Electric companies shall develop separate forecasts for each relevant DER type, including energy efficiency, demand response, distributed generation, energy storage devices, VPPs and managed EV charging-discharging.
Electric Companies shall develop hourly DER forecasts.
Load Forecast. Load forecasts shall account for the following considerations for each planning cycle and scenario as follows:
Electric companies shall incorporate load impacts of current and future transportation and building electrification based on known information and assumptions; and

Electric company distribution-level forecasts in aggregate shall be aligned to a reasonable extent with available electric company developed transmission-level forecasts and with PJM-developed system-level forecasts with an explanation provided in electric system plans for any differences and the associated factors, including differences in assumptions.
Hosting Capacity Assessment. An electric system plan shall account for the following considerations for each planning cycle and scenario.
Hosting capacity calculations shall be determined using a circuit-specific calculation including installed and forecasted DER interconnections.
DER forecasting shall be incorporated into reserve hosting capacity determinations and the rightsizing of hosting capacity upgrades.

Electric companies shall establish methodologies for calculating available hosting capacity and, in the annual electric system plan update and electric system plan, discuss planned hosting capacity capability improvements.
Grid Needs and Locational Value Assessment.
Grid Needs Assessment.

An electric company’s grid needs assessment shall include current and forecast distribution substation and feeder constraints identified as part of each planning cycle, including the timing, magnitude and other relevant characteristics for each identified system constraint.
The annual electric system plan update shall discuss changes to an electric company’s grid needs assessment that may occur between planning cycles.

Electric companies shall cost-effectively pursue industry best practice methods and analytical tools to improve their planning analysis and processes, the choice of which to adopt shall be at the discretion of the electric companies.
Locational Value Assessment.
An electric system plan shall provide locational value for each identified electric system constraint.
Locational value shall include the potential deferral or avoided value of a traditional wires solution.
Electric companies shall develop a locational value assessment using the Commission's uniform benefit cost analysis framework.
Electric companies shall report on the progress towards implementation of locational value assessments at annual technical conferences.
Identify Possible Solutions to Grid Needs. An electric system plan shall account for the following considerations for each planning cycle and scenario:
Near-Term Objective.
An electric system plan shall identify solutions for identified grid needs.
Electric companies shall identify non-wires solutions considered to address system constraints.
For any proposed upgrade projects resulting from Regulations .03H and .03I of this chapter, future hosting capacity constraints that incorporate DER forecasts shall be considered.
As A Longer-Term Objective.
Electric companies shall assess the feasibility of utilizing new cost-effective technologies and methodologies for solutions to grid needs.
Electric companies shall report on the progress towards utilizing new cost-effective technologies and methodologies at annual technical conferences.

Pursuant to Public Utilities Article, §7-804, Annotated Code of Maryland, electric companies shall consider investment in, or procurement of cost-effective demand-side methods and technology to improve reliability and efficiency, including VPPs.
Screen and Evaluate Possible Solutions.
An electric company shall screen and evaluate possible solutions for each planning cycle and scenario.
The electric system plan shall include the criteria used to evaluate possible solutions, including cost-effectiveness considerations.
Electric companies shall evaluate cost-effectiveness for alternatives considered, if applicable.
Electric companies shall utilize the Commission's Unified Benefit Cost Analysis framework for solutions involving DERs in determining cost-effectiveness.

Choose Solutions and Publish Plan. An electric company shall choose a solution or solutions for each scenario and publish a plan for each planning cycle as described in Regulation .04 of this chapter.
Electric companies shall present their rationale for solution selection in electric system plans, including why alternative solutions were not selected.
Information and data shall be provided in an electric system plan at the substation level.
When project solutions are proposed in response to system constraints, electric companies shall provide feeder-level information, where applicable.
Program and Project Design.

Program and project design including construction, procurement, and electric company contracting are factors in the electric companies’ mandate to provide safe and reliable service and a consideration in overall cost which shall be estimated in electric system plans.

Program and project design including construction, procurement, and electric company contracting decisions shall be left to electric company discretion in executing an electric system plan although these factors will remain subject to review in rate cases.
Assess Results. An electric company shall account for the following considerations for each planning cycle:
An electric company shall assess the results of their electric system plans to determine lessons learned and changes to future planning assumptions.
Rate case filings shall provide explanations for projects that do not reconcile with electric system plans.

section.heading: Electric System Plan, Annual Electric System Plan Update and Preliminary Electric System Plan: Development, Reporting, and Stakeholder Engagement Process.

para.text: Electric System Plan Frequency.

Electric companies shall retain flexibility to determine the frequency of their respective electric system plan that best aligns with their internal planning cycles and considerations based upon their unique processes, system characteristics, and customer needs.
An electric company’s electric system plan publishing frequency shall be at least once every 3 years.

Electric companies shall publish a preliminary electric system plan and the electric system plan on the electric companies’ websites and file these plans with the Commission under the electric system plan docket assigned to each electric company.
An electric company shall file an annual electric system plan update during the years in which a complete electric system plan is not filed.

An electric company shall redact all confidential information from the electric system plan published to its website or otherwise submitted on a public basis, however, a full version of the electric system plan, including any confidential information, shall be filed with the Commission in accordance with the Commission’s rules for filing confidential material, unless otherwise restricted from doing so by applicable law.
Annual Electric System Plan Update.
Electric companies shall include the following annual electric system plan updates:
A narrative describing the existing planning and forecasting processes, current capabilities that exist, and plans for potential future improvements;
Relevant planning criteria utilized to identify system constraints;
Description of any new market or policy conditions that are impacting the planning environment and how they plan to incorporate them into future planning;

Description of any updates to system constraints or constraint solutions that may have changed from the previous year, including, but not limited to, updates on progress regarding projects and programs that have changed from the previous year and rationale for the change;

A report using a common framework for electric company reporting as directed by the Commission, with information regarding the current status of projects designed to promote State policy goals identified in Public Utilities Article, §7-802, Annotated Code of Maryland, including information on planning processes and implementation that promote these goals; and
Electric system plan targets and planning metrics pursuant to Regulation .05 of this chapter.
Electric companies shall file an annual electric system plan update no less than 75 days prior to the annual technical conference.
In the year an electric company files a preliminary electric system plan, an annual electric system plan update is not required.
Data Collection: Electric companies shall identify a discrete opportunity to collect stakeholder inputs for consideration in the electric system plan.
The electric company shall provide an overview of the already-collected data including data sources.
Electric companies shall provide a method for collecting this data.
Electric companies shall provide a list of the parties they engaged as part of their published electric system plan.

Align Inputs and Assumptions. Electric companies shall develop electric system planning inputs and assumptions or develop forecasts, scenarios, or other electric system planning criteria and identify a discrete opportunity for stakeholders and other persons to provide feedback.

Run Analyses. Electric companies shall run analyses using data, planning inputs, and assumptions while considering stakeholder and other person feedback from §§C and D of this regulation and provide a preliminary electric system plan in years that an electric system plan is due.
Provide Preliminary Electric System Plan.
Electric companies shall include the following in their preliminary electric system plan:
Lessons learned and process improvements from the previous electric system plan cycle;

A narrative describing the existing electric system planning process, current capabilities, and plans for potential future changes including the methodology used to develop aggregate electric distribution-level net load forecasts;
Descriptions of electric system planning scenarios describing the data used as inputs and assumed adoption rates used for load and DER forecasting;
Summary of feedback received in §§C and D of this regulation;
Electric company response to feedback received in §§C and D of this regulation;
Any change in system constraints since the last electric system plan;
The nature, magnitude, and timing of system constraints;
System constraint solutions that have not yet been initiated as projects, including:
Projected timeline for solution implementation to address system constraints and policy targets over the forecast period; and
Implementation interdependencies with current and identified system constraint solutions and other electric company projects;
Cost-effectiveness analysis for identified system constraint solutions, if applicable;
A description of the final methodology, inputs, and results of the analyses;
Locational value for each identified system constraint; and
Electric system plan targets and planning metrics pursuant to Regulation .05 of this chapter.
The preliminary electric system plan shall be published to align with the electric system plan frequency pursuant to §A of this regulation.
An electric company shall publish on its website and file with the Commission its preliminary electric system plan no less than 75 days prior to the annual technical conference.
Comments Filed By Parties.
Comments shall be filed by any stakeholders or other persons no less than 30 days prior to the annual technical conference.
Stakeholders and electric companies shall have the opportunity to obtain discovery.

Annual Technical Conference. The annual technical conference shall provide a venue for stakeholders and other persons to comment on the assumptions, inputs, and results of the preliminary electric system plan and annual electric system plan update.
Electric Companies’ Consideration of Feedback.
The Commission may provide an order noting the preliminary electric system plan after an annual technical conference which may include direction for the electric companies.
Electric companies shall evaluate any feedback received from the Commission in any order following the annual technical conference.
Electric companies shall evaluate feedback received from stakeholders in §§C, D, G, and H of this regulation.

Within 90 days of the annual technical conference, except as otherwise required by the Commission, electric companies shall publish on their website and file a response to stakeholder and other person feedback with the Commission, including what stakeholder and other person proposals will be considered or not considered in the development of the electric system plan and the reasoning for these decisions under the electric system plan docket assigned to each electric company.

Electric System Plan Publishing. Electric companies shall publish a final electric system plan under the electric system plan docket assigned to each electric company after the consideration of feedback in Regulation .04I of this chapter.
An electric company shall include planning metrics listed in §C of this regulation in its preliminary electric system plan and other planning metrics as determined by the Commission.
An electric company shall include planning metrics listed in §C of this regulation in its annual electric system plan update and other planning metrics as determined by the Commission.

An electric company shall include in its preliminary electric system plan, electric system plan, and annual electric system plan update a set of planning metrics that will allow monitoring of progress in at minimum the following plan areas:
State goals and targets;
Reliability;
Resilience;
DER integration, by DER category;
Load and demand management;
Hosting capacity;
System constraint resolution including:
Substation overload conditions defined as overload conditions identified on substations that require remediation; and
Feeder overload conditions defined as overload conditions identified on substations that require remediation;
NWS incorporation; and
Stakeholder and other person engagement.
Annual Maryland General Assembly Report.
On or before November 1 annually, each electric company shall file material updates to project status reported pursuant to Regulation .04B(1)(e) of this chapter.

On or before December 1 annually, the Commission’s Technical Staff shall submit a report to the Maryland General Assembly regarding the current status of projects designed to promote the State’s policy goals identified in Public Utilities Article, §7-802, Annotated Code of Maryland, including information on planning processes and implementation that promote these goals.

section.heading: Requirements for an Election Plan.
section.text: A local board shall include in the election plan:

para.text: A polling place plan that meets the requirements of COMAR 33.15.03.01;
A ballot drop box plan developed in accordance with COMAR 33.11.01.04;
An early voting center plan that meets the requirements of COMAR 33.17.02.02;
An analysis of how to maximize voter participation in the county and each precinct; and
A letter from the local board that includes:
The date of the local board meeting where the election plan was considered;
A summary of any oral testimony about the election plan that was offered at the meeting where the election plan was considered;
As an attachment, any written testimony submitted by the public regarding the election plan; and
An affirmation of compliance with the notice and comment requirements of Election Law Article, §2-303.1(e)(3)(5), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The State Board shall:
Prescribe a form and submission process for a local board to use to provide a proposed election plan; and
Provide each local board with the prescribed form at least 9 months before a primary election.
Requirements of Election Plan Submission Process.
The form and submission process required under §A of this regulation shall ensure that an election plan meets the requirements of COMAR 33.01.08.01.

A local board shall submit an election plan by completing the form and submission process required under §A(1) of this regulation at least 7 months before each Statewide primary election. Completion of the form and submission process shall constitute fulfillment of a local board’s duty to submit an election plan pursuant to Election Law Article, §2-303.1(a), Annotated Code of Maryland.
Upon receipt of an election plan, the State Administrator shall review it and make a recommendation to the State Board whether to approve it.
The State Board shall:
Vote on a local board's proposed election plan within 30 days of receipt of the submission required in COMAR 33.01.08.02(B)(2);
Approve an election plan if the election plan:
Complies with the requirements of Election Law Article, §§2-303.1 and 10.101(a)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland;
Complies with this regulation and COMAR 33.15.03.01, 33.11.01.04, and 33.17.02.02;
Has been reviewed by the State Administrator; and
Will not negatively affect access to voting for historically disenfranchised communities, as defined in Election Law Article, §1-101(aa-1), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Within 2 days after its vote on an election plan, notify the local board of the State Board's vote.
If the State Board votes on an election plan and does not approve the election plan under §B(2) of this regulation, the State Board shall:
In the notice required by §B(3) of this regulation include:
The reason that the plan was not approved;
A statement that a revised plan is due 15 days after the vote by the State Board; and
The date on which the State Board will meet to review the revised plan.
Set a date for a meeting to consider the revised plan that is no later than 5 days after the submission date of the revised plan.
Upon approval by the State Board, a local board shall include in its disaster recovery plan the name, address, and contact information for each early voting center, polling place and ballot drop box.

section.heading: Notice of Proposed Election Plan by the Local Boards.

para.text: Contact List.
Each local board shall maintain a contact list of individuals and organizations as required by Election Law Article, §2-303.1(e)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland.
There shall be one list for the purposes of sending notices of election plans and polling place changes as required by Election Law Article, §2-303.1(e)(4), Annotated Code of Maryland.
Each local board shall make available in a conspicuous location on its website:
Information about the contact list in §A of this regulation, including:
A statement that the purpose of the list is to provide notice about local board meetings where an election plan or proposed change to a location of a polling place will be considered;
A statement that by signing up for the list, the person will receive notice of any meeting where election plans or polling place changes are considered; and
How to register for the list.
At least 14 days before a meeting where an election plan or polling place change will be discussed, the proposed election plan or written description of the proposed change in polling place.
At least 14 days before meeting to consider an election plan, the local board shall provide written notice of the meeting to:
Each individual and organization on the contact list required in §A of this regulation; and
The following elected officials who represent all or any portion of the county:
The Mayor;
County Executive;
County Commissioner;
County Council member;
Each Municipal Council member; and
Member of the General Assembly.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Cure list” means a list of all voters who returned a mail-in ballot, as of the date requested, but did not sign the oath document, for a single election.
“Early voting list” means a list of all individuals who, as of the date requested, voted during early voting for a single election.
Electoral Process.

“Electoral process” means the system established by the Maryland Constitution, Election Law Article, Annotated Code of Maryland, and regulations of the State Board, by which a person is elected to a public office or by which voters express a preference on a ballot question.

“Electoral process” includes, but is not limited to registering voters, forming political parties, qualifying as a candidate for public office, petitioning candidates or questions to the ballot, drafting and publishing ballot questions, conducting elections, casting ballots, canvassing ballots, recounting an election, and financing a campaign.
“Initial voter list” means a list of all individuals who, as of the date requested, meet the criteria requested by the individual requesting the list.
“Mail-in list” means a list of all registered voters who, as of the date requested, have requested a mail-in ballot for a single Statewide election.
“Permanent mail-in applicant list” means a list of all registered voters who, as of the date requested, have requested a mail-in ballot for all future Statewide elections.
“Provisional list” means a list of all individuals who, as of the date requested, cast a provisional ballot for a single election.

“Supplemental voter list” means a list of all individuals who, from the date of an initial voter list through a later requested date, meet the criteria requested by the individual requesting the list.
"Voter registration list" means:
A cure list;
An early voting list;
An initial registered voter list;
A mail-in list;
A permanent mail-in list;
A provisional list;
A supplemental registered voter list; or
Any other list of voters requested and approved by the State Administrator.

The State Administrator shall prescribe a form to collect information sufficient to determine whether an individual is qualified to serve as an election judge and can fulfill the duties of an election judge.

The State prescribed form from applicants to be election judges; or
An electronic application form that has been approved by the State Administrator.

Either IRS Form W-4 or IRS Form W-9;
IRS Form I-9;
Maryland Form MW-507.

para.text: Each election director shall provide notice of all absentee canvasses and the provisional canvass by:
Mail or email sent directly to:
The chairman of the county central committee of each political party;
Each candidate who is not a candidate of a political party; and
The State Administrator; and
Posting a notice on the local board's website and in a prominent and publicly accessible location at the local board's office.
The election director shall send the notice at least 10 days before the first absentee canvass.

The election director may include the notice for the pre-election public demonstration required by Election Law Article, Subtitle 10, Annotated Code of Maryland, in the notice required under this regulation.

section.heading: Voting System Verification.
section.text: A local board shall test the voting system as provided in COMAR 33.10 for accuracy.

para.text: A board of canvassers may not certify and transmit a copy of election results, pursuant to Election Law Article, §11-401(a)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland, until after the deadline for receipt of timely mail-in ballots provided by COMAR 33.11.03.08B(4)(a).

If a board of canvassers is unable to certify election results on the second Friday after election day, the board of canvassers, in consultation with the election director, shall notify in writing the State Board of Elections of the delay.
The notification shall contain:
Detailed plan on the continuation of the canvass including staffing figures, dates, and hours to be worked;
The number of outstanding ballots to be canvassed; and
An anticipated end date for the canvass and certification of election results.

The State Board of Elections has the authority to modify the plan to ensure completion of the canvass and certification of election results in a timely manner for State certification and any post-election audits.

para.text: Factors for Determining Ballot Drop Box Locations. A local board shall use the following factors when determining the location of a ballot drop box:
Accessibility of the ballot drop box to historically disenfranchised communities, including voters with disabilities, cultural groups, ethnic groups, and minority groups;
Proximity of the ballot drop box to dense concentrations of voters such that:
If a county has fewer than 200,000 registered voters, 75 percent of the registered voters in the county live within 10 miles of a proposed ballot drop box; or
If a county has 200,000 or more registered voters, 90 percent of the registered voters live within 5 miles of a proposed ballot drop box.
Accessibility of the ballot drop box by public transportation; and
Ensuring equitable geographic distribution of ballot drop boxes throughout the county.
Requirements for Ballot Drop Boxes Locations.
Each ballot drop box location shall have security cameras to monitor the box at all times.
The images from each security camera shall be made available to the local board immediately or within a reasonable amount of time of a request from the State Administrator or local board.
Approval Process for Ballot Drop Box Plan.
The State Administrator shall:
Prescribe a form for a local board to use to provide information about a proposed ballot drop box; and
Provide each local board with the form at least 9 months before a primary election.
The form shall:
Include questions related to whether the proposed ballot drop box meets the factors and requirements defined in §§A and B of this regulation; and,

If a proposed ballot drop box does not satisfy all of the factors defined in §A of this regulation, allow the local board to list other locations that were considered and why they were not proposed and describe the factors that mitigate the fact that the proposed ballot drop box location does not meet the factors defined in §A of this regulation.
At least 7 months before a primary election, the local board shall submit a ballot drop box plan to the State Administrator including:
A form for each proposed ballot drop box; and
Forms for all proposed ballot drop boxes at the same time.
The State Administrator shall approve a proposed location that meets the factors defined in §A of this regulation.
If the State Administrator determines that a proposed ballot drop box plan does not meet the factors defined in §A of this regulation, before the ballot drop box plan is submitted to the State Board:
Within 2 days of making the determination, the State Administrator shall provide the local board with a detailed explanation of why the proposed plan does not meet the factors;

The State Administrator shall request that the local board reconsider the proposed location for one or more ballot drop boxes and propose one or more other locations that meet the factors defined in §A of this regulation; and
Within 7 days of receiving the State Administrator's detailed explanation, the local board shall:
Propose one or more locations that meet the factors defined in §A of this regulation; or
Explain why a location that meets the factors defined in §A of this regulation cannot be proposed and propose the location of an additional ballot drop box.
The State Administrator may add additional ballot drop box locations:

If, after reconsideration and resubmission by the local board pursuant to §C(5) of this regulation, the State Administrator determines that the proposed ballot drop box location does not meet the factors in §A of this regulation;

If a local board of elections proposes fewer drop boxes than in a previously comparable statewide election and fails to justify the reduction in drop boxes in reference to the factors in §A, it is presumed that the factors defined in §A are not sufficiently met.
Electioneering Boundary.

The local board shall post signs delineating an area around each ballot box where a person may not electioneer. A local board is not required to delineate this area with a physical line on the ground.

Except as provided in §D(3) of this regulation, the line shall be located as near as practicable to 50 feet from the ballot box after consideration of the placement of the ballot box and the effect of placement on public safety and the flow of pedestrian and vehicular traffic.
If the ballot box is placed within the electioneering boundary of a polling place, the line for the ballot box shall be the electioneering boundary of the polling place.
The signs shall contain the words “No Electioneering Beyond this Point.”
Electioneering Activities.
The following activities are not permitted within the electioneering boundary set forth in §D of this regulation:
Electioneering by individuals; or
Observing or recording voter activities by a group of affiliated individuals.

An individual observing a ballot box or recording activities within the electioneering boundary set forth in §D of this regulation is not electioneering if the person is not communicating with, questioning, or otherwise interfering with voters dropping off materials at a ballot box.
Other Activities.
Except as provided in §F(2) of this regulation, an individual may not visibly possess, visibly carry, or brandish a firearm within the electioneering boundary set forth in §D of this regulation.
A law enforcement officer or security guard who is on duty or traveling to or from duty may enter the electioneering boundary set forth in §D of this regulation to drop off materials at a ballot box.
A person may observe an election official remove materials from the ballot box if the person does not interfere with the process.

para.text: Requirements for Polling Place Plan. A local board shall include in the polling place plan:
Evidence that the plan complies with Election Law Article, §10-101(a)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland;

In a Statewide election except for the first election immediately following statewide redistricting based on the census, if the polling place plan proposes to reduce the number of separate buildings used as polling places below the total number of separate buildings used as polling places in the first statewide general election held after the most recent Statewide redistricting based on the census:
The address and a description of the location of each affected polling place;

An analysis of available suitable buildings within the precinct boundary, including the availability of parking and a determination regarding building compliance with the federal Americans with Disabilities Act;
Of the voters who cast ballots in each affected precinct in the three most recent Statewide elections:
The percentage who voted in person on election day;
The percentage who voted by mail;
The number who registered to vote on election day; and
The number who voted at an early voting center;
Proximity of the proposed polling place to a dense concentration of voters in the affected precinct;
The change in the number of registered voters in the affected precinct from the last Statewide election;
The public transportation options that voters in each affected precinct could use to access the polling place that would serve the precinct under the plan; and
An analysis of the impact on the ability of historically disenfranchised communities to cast a ballot, including demographic information of the voters in the affected precinct.

In the first Statewide election held after a Statewide redistricting based on the census, if the polling place plan proposes to reduce the total number of separate buildings used as polling places below the total number of separate buildings used as polling places in the immediately preceding general election:
The address and a description of the location of each affected polling place;

An analysis of available suitable buildings within the precinct boundary, including the availability of parking and a determination regarding building compliance with the federal Americans with Disabilities Act;
Of the voters who cast ballots in each affected precinct in the three most recent Statewide elections:
The percentage who voted in person on election day;
The percentage who voted by mail;
The number who registered to vote on election day; and
The number who voted at an early voting center;
The proximity of the proposed polling place to a dense concentration of voters in the affected precinct;
The change in the number of registered voters in the affected precinct from the last Statewide election;
The public transportation options that voters in each affected precinct could use to access the polling place that would serve the precinct under the plan; and
An analysis of the impact on the ability of historically disenfranchised communities to cast a ballot, including demographic information of the voters in the affected precinct.
Form for Polling Place Plan.
The State Board shall:
Prescribe a form for a local board to use to provide a proposed polling place plan; and
Provide each local board with the form at least 9 months before a primary election.
Contents of Form. The form shall include questions related to whether the proposed polling place plan meets the requirements in §A of this regulation.

Form Submission. A local board shall submit the form at least 7 months before each Statewide primary election. Completion and submission of the form shall constitute fulfillment of a local board’s duty to submit a polling place plan pursuant to Election Law Article, §2-303.1(a), Annotated Code of Maryland.
Additional Information. For each polling place plan, a local board shall submit with the form required in §B of this regulation:
A Polling Place Selection Form;
The State of Maryland’s Accessibility Survey form for each polling place;
Documentation of the local board’s approval of the polling place plan;
A polling place diagram;
Photographs of the interior and exterior of each polling place; and

If required by §A(2) or (3) of this regulation, documentation to support the determination that all buildings that will no longer be used as polling places are no longer suitable to be used as polling places.
Board Action Required to Change the Location of a Polling Place. A local board may not vote to change the location of a polling place unless the local board first:
Holds a meeting to discuss the proposed change; and
Provides an opportunity for interested parties to testify on the proposed change at the meeting.
Notice of Proposed Changes.

Each local board shall maintain a contact list of individuals and organizations who wish to be notified about local board meetings at which an election plan or any proposed changes to the locations of polling places will be discussed.
Each local board shall make available in a conspicuous location on its website:
Information about the contact list in §B(1) of this regulation, including:

A statement that the purpose of the list is to provide notice about local board meetings where an election plan or proposed change to a location of a polling place will be considered, in fulfillment of this regulation and COMAR 33.01.08.04(a).
A statement that by signing up for the list the person will receive notice of any meeting where election plans or polling place changes are considered; and
How to register for the list.
At least 14 days before a meeting where an election plan or polling place change will be discussed, the proposed election plan or written description of the proposed change in polling place.
At least 14 days before meeting to consider a change of a polling place, the local board shall provide written notice of the meeting to:
Each individual and organization on the contact list; and
The following elected officials who represent the precinct containing either the current polling place location or its proposed location:
The Mayor;
County Executive;
County Commissioner;
County Council member;
Each Municipal Council member; and
Member of the General Assembly.

Exception for Emergency Changes. The requirements of §§A and B of this regulation do not apply if a local board determines that an emergency exists that requires a change to the polling place location during the period beginning 21 days before election day through election day.
Notice Required to Voters.
Whenever a local board changes the location of a polling place, the local board shall notify all voters who are affected by the change.
Except as provided in §D(3)(b) of this regulation, the local board shall mail this notice to the affected voters before the next election.
How and When — Emergencies.
If an emergency prevents compliance with §B of this regulation, the local board shall:
Take whatever steps it considers reasonable to notify affected voters of the change; and
Inform the State Administrator of the change and the steps being taken to notify voters.
The notice required by this section:
Shall include a prominent notice posted at the former polling place; and
May include television, radio, and newspaper announcements and advertisements and postings on the Internet.

para.text: Factors for Location of Early Voting Centers. A local board shall [consider] use the following factors when determining the location of an early voting center:
Accessibility of the early voting center to historically disenfranchised communities, including cultural groups, ethnic groups, and minority groups;
Proximity of the early voting center to dense concentrations of voters such that:

If a county is required by Regulation .01 of this chapter to have one or two early voting centers, 50 percent of the registered voters in the county live within 10 miles of a proposed early voting center; or
If a county is required by Regulation .01 of this chapter to have three or more early voting centers, 80 percent of the registered voters live within 5 miles of a proposed early voting centers;
Accessibility of the early voting center by public transportation;
If a county is required by Regulation .01 of this chapter to have four or more early voting centers, ensuring equitable geographic distribution of early voting centers throughout the county;
Use of community centers and public gathering places as locations for early voting centers;
Whether the early voting center can accommodate long lines of voters, including taking into consideration how voters waiting in line are protected against inclement weather; and
Whether the early voting center has parking facilities sufficient for early voting, taking into consideration the normal business activities of the proposed early voting center.
Requirements for Early Voting Centers. A local board shall propose early voting center locations that:
Allow a local board to install the required telecommunication needs;
Are of sufficient size and layout to conduct early voting, including adequate access to electricity;
Are accessible or can be made accessible for voters with disabilities;
Can store voting equipment and supplies in a secure location during non-early voting hours;
Have sufficient and reliable heating and air-conditioning capabilities; and

Can accommodate a no electioneering zone as required by Election Law Article, §16-206, Annotated Code of Maryland, exit polling as required by COMAR 33.07.08, and electioneering outside of the no-electioneering zone.
Form for Proposed Early Voting Center.
The State Board shall:
Prescribe a form for a local board to use to provide information about a proposed early voting center; and
Provide each local board with the form at least 9 months before a primary election.
Form Submission for Early Voting Center.
At least 7 months before a primary election, a local board shall submit a form for each proposed early voting center.
If a local board is required to have more than one early voting center, the local board shall:
Complete a form for each proposed early voting center; and
Submit the forms for each proposed early voting centers at the same time.
A local board shall submit early voting center proposal forms together with all other information required for the election plan in COMAR 33.01.08.01.
Contents of Form. The form shall include questions related to whether the proposed early voting center meets the factors and requirements defined in §§A and B of this regulation.
Additional Information. For each proposed early voting center, a local board shall submit with the form required in §C of this regulation:

A diagram of the facility, including the proposed layout of the voting equipment and electrical and telecommunications connections in the voting area and the proposed locations of the election judges;
The State of Maryland's Accessibility Survey form;
Digital photographs of the outside of and entrance to the proposed early voting center; and
The security plan required by Regulation .04 of this chapter.

Inability to Identify Proposed Early Voting Center. If the proposed early voting center does not meet all of the criteria listed on the form required in §C of this regulation, a local board shall provide on the form:
A list of other facilities that were considered, and why those facilities are not being proposed as early voting centers; and
A description of the factors that mitigate the fact that the proposed early voting center does not meet all of the criteria listed on the form required in §C of this regulation.
Use of Local Board Office. If a local board proposes to use the offices of the local board as an early voting center, the local board shall:
Have a clearly marked space for early voting that is distinct and separate from absentee voting that occurs at the office; and
Post signs and include in all election-specific materials the business hours of the local board and the early voting hours.
Optional Early Voting Centers.
In addition to the early voting centers required in this subsection, each county may establish one additional early voting center if:
First, the local board and the governing body of the county agree to establish an additional early voting center; and
Then, the State Board approves the establishment of the additional early voting center.
In approving an additional early voting center, the governing body of the county must acknowledge the following in writing:
The approval of the additional center is for the next Statewide election cycle, unless the governing body specifies approval for all future elections; and
Once approved for the next Statewide election cycle, that approval cannot be rescinded.
In approving an additional early voting center, the State Board shall consider the requirements of §B of this regulation, but need not consider the factors in §A of this regulation.

Use of a Public Building. If a local board proposes to use a public building as an early voting center, the local board shall give written notice of intent to the public official with responsibility for the public building.
Alternate Early Voting Centers.
A local board shall identify an alternate early voting center for use if an approved early voting center becomes unavailable.
A local board shall give preference to the offices of the local board or a government facility when considering the location of an alternate early voting center.
A local board shall identify:
One alternate early voting center if the local board is required to establish one, two, or three early voting centers; or
Two alternate early voting centers if the local board is required to establish four or more early voting centers.
A local board shall:
At least 3 months before a primary election, complete and submit to the State Administrator the form required by §C of this regulation for each proposed alternate early voting center; and
Upon approval by the State Administrator of the alternate early voting center:
Submit the form to the appropriate local government agencies; and

Include in its disaster recovery plan the name, address, and contact information for each alternate early voting center, a plan for notifying the public if the alternate center is needed, and a plan for transitioning operations to an alternate center.
